snippet: The college’s resistance in a 79-1 vote in January provided a reminder of disparities among the 65 members of the N.C.A.A.’s so-called Big 5 athletic conferences.
abstract: Marc Tracy On College Sports column examines Boston College's lone dissent in NCAA ballot to increase the allowed value of scholarship to cover federally determined cost of attendance; observes that college wanted to emphasize how shift would increase expenses, segregate athletes from other students and create dangerous wiggle room for recruiting advantage.
lead_paragraph: The college’s resistance in a 79-1 vote in January provided a reminder of disparities among the 65 members of the N.C.A.A.’s so-called Big 5 athletic conferences.

headline.print_headline: Boston College Seeks to Give Others Pause in the Overhaul of Scholarships
